importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The research voyage took place in late 2022, marking the start of a significant deep-sea exploration in the Gascoyne Marine Park that led to the discovery of multiple new species.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The deep-sea exploration took place at depths ranging from 122 meters to over 600 meters below sea level, where extreme pressure and darkness foster unique adaptations in marine life.

keyTakeAways: A semi-transparent porcelain crab, about 1.5cm in size, was discovered in the deep sea near Western Australia, using hairs to catch food instead of claws.
A new species of lantern shark, the West Australian Lantern Shark, was found at depths over 600m, featuring large eyes and bioluminescent glow on its belly.
The discovery highlights Australia’s rich but underexplored deep-sea biodiversity, especially in the Gascoyne Marine Park.
Over 20 new species have been identified from the 2022 research voyage, with scientists estimating 600 more yet to be formally described and named.
The findings emphasize the importance of deep-sea exploration and the unique adaptations of marine life in extreme environments.

namedEntities.name: Australia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country in the southern hemisphere, one of the world's biodiversity hotspots.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Australia is highlighted as a region with vast, unexplored deep-sea ecosystems where new species are being discovered, contributing to global biodiversity knowledge.

namedEntities.name: CSIRO
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Australia's national science agency responsible for conducting scientific research.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CSIRO led the deep-sea research expedition in the Gascoyne Marine Park, playing a central role in the discovery of new species.

namedEntities.name: Gascoyne Marine Park
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A marine protected area located approximately 20km off the coast of Western Australia.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The primary location of the deep-sea research voyage where the new species were discovered.

namedEntities.name: West Australian Lantern Shark
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly described species of bioluminescent lantern shark found at depths over 600m.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This species is one of the key discoveries, exhibiting unique biological traits such as glowing belly and large eyes adapted to deep-sea conditions.

namedEntities.name: Porcelain Crab
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A small crab species with modified mouthparts and hairs used to catch food.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The new porcelain crab species discovered is notable for its filter-feeding behavior, different from typical crab feeding methods.

namedEntities.name: Carnavon Flapjack Octopus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly discovered octopus species approximately 4cm in size with a rusty red color.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the 20 new species identified from the 2022 expedition, adding to the growing list of unique marine life in Australian waters.

namedEntities.name: Dr Will White
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A fish scientist at CSIRO, involved in the research.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provided expert insight into the bioluminescent characteristics of the lantern shark species.

namedEntities.name: Dr Andrew Hosie
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Curator of aquatic zoology at the Western Australian Museum.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He explained the unique feeding mechanism of the porcelain crab, offering scientific context to the discovery.

namedEntities.name: Western Australia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A state within Australia, where the research site is located.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The research took place off the coast of Western Australia, indicating regional focus and ecological significance.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Australian scientists from CSIRO discovered two new species during a deep-sea expedition in the Gascoyne Marine Park in late 2022: a tiny porcelain crab about 1.5cm long using hairs to filter food and a bioluminescent lantern shark with large eyes found over 600 meters below sea level. These discoveries underscore Australia’s rich but largely unexplored marine biodiversity, with over 20 new species identified and an estimated 600 more awaiting formal description due to the time required for scientific validation.
title: Australia: Almond-sized crab and tiny lantern shark discovered in deep seas
